title: Americans are Snapping Up Bidets, But Does Your Bathroom Need One?
sub_head: Some argue the washlets offer a healthier, more soothing cleanse. Others contend the fussy fixtures create more problems than they solve. Choose your side.
body:
For the recurring series, That’s Debatable, we take on a contentious issue of the day and present two spirited arguments—one in favor and the other emphatically opposed. Previous installments from the series are here.
AS A REAL-ESTATE AGENT in Goldsboro N.C., Johnny Cox, 49, often finds inspiration and ideas while watching HGTV. One day a few years ago, he saw an almost-forgot-about-those feature being installed in a bathroom: a bidet. Bidets were once relatively uncommon in America, industrious but cosmopolitan devices that sat next to one’s toilet, and allowed one to clean oneself with a gentle spray of water. The version Mr. Cox spied was a more modern bidet attachment, an easier-to-install electric retrofit.
